weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

countermeasure.name: Enforce least privilege and regularly audit user permissions
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all user profiles in AWS Connect are configured with the minimum permissions necessary to perform their roles effectively. Implement the principle of least privilege by assigning only those permissions required for specific tasks, reducing the risk of unauthorized actions or privilege escalation. Additionally, regularly audit user permissions to identify and remove any excessive or outdated access rights. Use AWS IAM Access Analyzer and other auditing tools to review permission sets and ensure compliance with security policies. This ongoing process helps maintain a secure environment by limiting the potential for internal threats and minimizing the impact of any compromised accounts.

countermeasure.name: Enforce Service Control Policies to protect critical resources from deletion
countermeasure.desc: To maintain the continuity and availability of your AWS Connect services, enforce Service Control Policies (SCPs) that explicitly prevent the deletion of critical resources such as Amazon Connect instances and associated IAM roles. SCPs act as guardrails that limit the actions users and roles can perform, even if they have administrative permissions. Implement an SCP at the organizational level to deny deletion actions (iam:DeleteRole and connect:DeleteInstance) on these critical resources. This ensures that no user or process can accidentally or maliciously remove essential components, safeguarding the stability and security of your contact center environment. Regularly review and update the SCPs to align with any changes in your resource configurations.

countermeasure.name: Implement Content Security Policy (CSP) and secure DOM manipulation in chat applications
countermeasure.desc: To protect against cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks in AWS Connect chat applications, implement a robust Content Security Policy (CSP) that restricts the sources from which your application can load scripts, styles, and other resources. This helps to prevent the execution of malicious code. Additionally, avoid directly mutating the Document Object Model (DOM) by using functions like innerHTML to insert content into the web page. Instead, use secure methods, such as libraries that sanitize and encode user inputs (e.g., React), to render chat responses safely. This practice ensures that any content dynamically added to your web pages does not expose your application to XSS vulnerabilities.

countermeasure.name: Monitor and audit access to recordings and sensitive data
countermeasure.desc: Implement continuous monitoring and auditing of all access to recordings and other sensitive data within AWS Connect to detect and prevent unauthorized access. Use AWS CloudTrail to log all requests and actions related to sensitive resources, and set up alerts for any suspicious or unusual activity. Ensure that access logs are stored securely and reviewed regularly for compliance and security purposes. Additionally, restrict access to sensitive data to only those users and roles that absolutely need it, and use fine-grained permissions to minimize exposure. This approach helps in early detection of potential breaches and ensures that all access to critical data is accountable and traceable.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental deletion of critical resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Accidental deletion of critical resources refers to the unintentional removal of essential components within AWS Connect, such as instances, IAM roles, or configuration settings. This can occur due to user error or misconfigured automation scripts, leading to significant disruptions in service availability and functionality.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Internal users with elevated permissions, automated processes, or misconfigured scripts.
  • Attack Vectors: Unintended actions by administrators, such as mistakenly deleting key resources, or poorly tested scripts that remove critical components.

Impacts

  • Service Disruption: Loss of availability for AWS Connect services, potentially leading to downtime for customer-facing applications.
  • Data Loss: Permanent deletion of important data or configurations that are crucial for service operations.
  • Recovery Challenges: Time-consuming and complex recovery processes that might involve restoring from backups or reconfiguring services from scratch.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An administrator mistakenly deletes the primary Amazon Connect instance instead of a test environment, causing an immediate service outage and requiring a full recovery operation.
  2. A poorly tested automation script unintentionally removes IAM roles associated with AWS Connect, cutting off user access and disrupting operations until roles are recreated and permissions are restored.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate user permission management
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate User Permission Management occurs when users are granted excessive permissions within AWS Connect, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive data and critical operations. This mismanagement increases the risk of data breaches and operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Internal employees, contractors, or external attackers with access to overly permissive accounts.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting misconfigured IAM roles or compromised credentials to perform unauthorized actions.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive customer information.
  • Service Disruption: Unintended or malicious changes causing service outages.
  • Compliance Risks: Violations of legal standards like GDPR or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A user with excessive permissions deletes a critical Amazon Connect instance, causing service downtime.
  2. An attacker with admin access siphons off sensitive call recordings, leading to a data breach.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized access to sensitive data occurs when individuals, either internal or external, gain access to confidential information within AWS Connect without proper authorization. This can lead to data breaches, where sensitive customer or organizational information is exposed or exploited.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized users exploiting weak access controls.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting poorly managed permissions, compromised credentials, or unmonitored access points.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of personal customer data, leading to financial and reputational damage.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches of legal and regulatory requirements, such as GDPR, resulting in fines.
  • Trust Erosion: Loss of customer trust and potential revenue decline due to perceived insecurity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses stolen credentials to access and download customer call recordings, leading to a significant data breach.
  2. An insider with unauthorized access retrieves sensitive client information and sells it on the black market, compromising customer privacy and trust.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Vulnerabilities in chat integration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Vulnerabilities in chat integration arise when security flaws in the implementation of chat features within AWS Connect allow attackers to exploit these weaknesses, potentially leading to unauthorized access, data leakage, or injection of malicious code. This is particularly critical when chat systems are integrated directly into web applications.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious users, or automated bots targeting weak points in chat functionality.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities, injecting malicious payloads via chat inputs, or intercepting unencrypted chat communications.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive customer interactions and data transmitted via chat could be intercepted or manipulated.
  • Service Disruption: Exploiting vulnerabilities to disrupt the chat service or degrade user experience.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust due to compromised chat functionality and potential data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits an XSS vulnerability in the chat interface, injecting malicious scripts that execute in the browser of anyone interacting with the chat, leading to data theft or account compromise.
  2. A poorly secured chat integration allows an attacker to hijack chat sessions, impersonate customer support, and obtain sensitive information from unsuspecting customers.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

weakness.name: CWE-1021
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1021: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with. A web application is expected to place restrictions on whether it is allowed to be rendered within frames, iframes, objects, embed or applet elements. Without the restrictions, users can be tricked into interacting with the application when they were not intending to.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

countermeasure.name: Avoid unsafe DOM manipulation and isolate untrusted scripts
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of a web client application, it is crucial to avoid the use of methods such as innerHTML and document.write for inserting dynamic content, as they can expose the application to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. Instead, implement JavaScript sandboxing techniques to restrict script execution and limit the impact of potential malicious code. Follow these steps to effectively apply these practices:

  1. Avoid using innerHTML and document.write:
    • Whenever possible, use textContent or innerText when inserting user-generated content into the DOM. These methods escape HTML, preventing the execution of any injected scripts.
    • For generating dynamic HTML content, use DOM manipulation methods like createElement, appendChild, or insertAdjacentElement.
  2. Implement Strict Content Security Policy (CSP):
    • Define a CSP policy that limits where resources can be loaded from and prevent inline scripts from executing without specific nonce or hash attributes.
    • Update the server configuration to include a secure CSP header. For example, configure your web server to send a header like: Content-Security-Policy: script-src 'self'.
  3. Utilize JavaScript sandboxing:
    • Use iframe elements with the sandbox attribute to run potentially untrusted scripts in a restricted execution environment.
    • Define sandbox rules to disable certain capabilities such as form submissions or plugin usage by including restrictions like sandox="allow-same-origin allow-scripts", while continuously adjusting these based on real application needs and security assessments.
  4. Apply libraries and frameworks for secure data binding:
    • Consider utilizing frontend frameworks such as React, Angular, or Vue.js, which inherently handle safe data binding and abstraction layers to reduce direct DOM manipulation.
    • These libraries offer protection features and methods against XSS due to their managed templating systems.
  5. Regularly update and audit code:
    • Ensure that your codebase and dependencies are regularly updated to mitigate known vulnerabilities.
    • Perform security audits and code reviews focusing on areas where user input impacts DOM manipulation.

By following these guidelines, you can mitigate risks associated with unsafe DOM manipulation and script execution, enhancing the overall security posture of your web client application.

References

  • MDN Web Docs - innerHTML Security Considerations
  • Content Security Policy (CSP) Reference
  • React Documentation - Introducing JSX
  • Angular Guide - Security

countermeasure.name: Detect and block UI redressing attempts
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the web client by preventing clickjacking attacks, follow these JavaScript-based frame-busting implementation steps:

  1. Function Initialization: Ensure the JavaScript function is executed as soon as the document is loaded. This can be done by placing the script at the end of the HTML body or attaching it to the window's onLoad event as shown in the example.
    1. window.onLoad = function() {    // Detect if the page is in an iframe    if (window.top !== window.self) {        window.top.location = window.self.location;    } }
  2. Frame-busting Script Logic: Implement a simple check within your JavaScript to detect whether the current webpage is being loaded within an iframe. This can be achieved by checking if window.top is equal to window.self.
  3. Redirection: If the webpage is inside an iframe, redirect the top frame to the current page's location. This effectively pulls the website out of the iframe and prevents the site from being embedded.
  4. Deploy and Test: After embedding this script in your application, ensure it correctly prevents your page from being displayed in any iframe. Conduct thorough testing to verify that normal usage is unaffected while iframe attempts are appropriately blocked.
  5. Detecting Overlays: Use client-side scripts to detect unexpected overlays. This involves monitoring the DOM for unauthorized inserted elements.

For this, include event listeners on dynamic DOM changes using MutationObservers, and if any suspicious elements are detected, take actions, such as denying access to specific features or alerting the user.

const observer = new MutationObserver((mutations) => {    mutations.forEach((mutation) => {        // Logic to detect and respond to unauthorized overlay or UI changes        if (/* some condition to identify a suspicious DOM node */) {            alert('Suspicious activity detected!');            // Optionally take further action, like removing the element        }    }); }); observer.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true });

  1. Start Observing DOM: Use the MutationObserver API to watch changes in the DOM structure. Observe body elements to catch any suspicious insertions or changes.
  2. Define Conditions: Specify what constitutes an unexpected overlay based on your applications expected behavior and UI state. For instance, look for fullscreen unauthorized dialog boxes.
  3. Handle Detected Anomalies: If a breakpoint is detected, you can either alert the user directly or log out activities for further review while limiting available actions.

References

  • MDN Web Docs: Window.self
  • MDN Web Docs: MutationObserver
  • OWASP: Clickjacking Defense

countermeasure.name: Ensure secure communication and validate external resources
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Web Client, it is crucial to enforce HTTPS with strong TLS (Transport Layer Security) configurations, ensuring the encryption and integrity of data transmitted between the client and server.

  1. Configure HTTPS:
    1. Obtain an SSL/TLS certificate from a trusted Certificate Authority (CA).
    2. Configure your web server (such as Apache, Nginx, or IIS) to use the obtained certificate. Refer to your server documentation for specific instructions.
    3. Ensure that all content, including images, scripts, and stylesheets, are served over HTTPS to avoid mixed content issues.
    4. Set up automatic HTTPS redirection by implementing HTTP to HTTPS redirects, ensuring that all traffic to your web client is encrypted.
  2. Implement Strong TLS Configurations:
    1. Disable outdated and vulnerable protocols (e.g., TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1) and enforce the use of TLS 1.2 or higher.
    2. Configure your web server to use strong cipher suites, removing support for weak ones. Ensure that Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) is enabled to provide additional security.
    3. Regularly review and update your server configurations to adhere to the latest security guidelines and best practices.
  3. Disable HTTP/2 Prioritization Attack Risk:
    1. Ensure HTTP/2 prioritization is implemented correctly, or disable it if not needed, to prevent attack vectors that exploit the feature.
  4. Validate External Resources with Subresource Integrity (SRI):
    1. Edit the HTML of your web client to include the integrity attribute on any <script> or <link> tags that load content from external sources.
    2. Generate the integrity hash value for the resource. Use a tool like SRI Hash Generator by pasting the URL of the external resource or the content itself.
    3. Include the generated hash within the integrity attribute of your HTML tags, specifying a hash algorithm such as SHA-384 or SHA-512.
    4. Regularly audit and update the SRI hashes whenever external resources are updated to ensure proper validation continues.

References

  • Let's Encrypt - Getting Started
  • Mozilla Developer Network - HTTP Strict Transport Security
  • OWASP Transport Layer Protection Cheat Sheet
  • Mozilla Security Server Side TLS Guide
  • Mozilla Developer Network - Subresource Integrity

countermeasure.name: Prevent storage of sensitive data on the client
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of a web client, it's crucial to handle sensitive information such as authentication tokens, API keys, and personally identifiable information (PII) with care. Here's a step-by-step guide to ensuring these data types are protected:

  1. Assessment of Current Storage Practices:

    • Audit current methods for storing sensitive information within your web client.
    • Identify any instances where information is stored in local storage, session storage, or client-side databases.

  2. Implement Secure Storage Practices:

    • Avoid storing sensitive values like authentication tokens or API keys in session storage or local storage whenever possible to reduce the risk of exposure.
    • If unavoidable, use secure alternatives such as storing temporary session data on server-side sessions.

  3. Encryption of Data:

    • If local storage is imperative, leverage encryption to secure your data. Use the Web Crypto API to encrypt data before storing it on the client-side.
    • Generate a cryptographic key using the Web Crypto API's `generateKey` method.
    • Use the `subtle.encrypt` method of the Web Crypto API to encrypt sensitive data before storage.
    • Ensure you store the keys securely and consider using server-side sessions or a secure cookie-based mechanism for sensitive token and key exchange.

  4. Information Minimization:

    • Only store data that is absolutely necessary for client operation, reducing the amount of sensitive information available to potential attackers.

  5. Regular Security Reviews:

    • Conduct regular security reviews and penetration tests to ensure data storage practices remain secure against emerging vulnerabilities and threats.

References

  • MDN Web Crypto API Documentation
  • OWASP Top Ten - Sensitive Data Exposure
  • Google Developers - Store Credentials Securely

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Clickjacking
threat.desc:
General threat description
An attacker manipulates a web page by overlaying a hidden or disguised user interface element to deceive users into executing actions without their awareness.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals or malicious entities who create or distribute tampered HTML or JavaScript code that modifies the user interface on a web page.
Impacts
This can lead to unauthorized transactions, data breaches, or compromise of user data due to users being misled into clicking or entering information into malicious forms.
Example Attack Scenarios
A user visits a banking website where a strategically placed invisible button overlays the legitimate 'Submit' button, causing the user to unknowingly authorize a funds transfer to an attacker's account.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Cross-site scripting
threat.desc:
General threat description
An attacker can inject harmful scripts into a web page that execute in the victim's browser, causing unauthorized access to session information, theft of sensitive data, and forcing the user to perform unintended operations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors typically use methods such as input fields, URLs, or stored data that are improperly validated or sanitized in web applications to introduce the malicious scripts.
Impacts
The compromise of user account confidentiality, integrity, and availability, leading to potential unauthorized access to sensitive account information, financial loss, or damage to user reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
A criminal leverages a vulnerable comment section on a website to post a script that captures cookies from users accessing the page, allowing the attacker to impersonate them for fraudulent transactions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Client-side insecure data storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper storage of sensitive information within the browser, such as authentication tokens or personal data, which can be extracted or manipulated by malicious entities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious attackers who are able to access and exploit vulnerabilities in the browser storage system to retrieve sensitive information.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to user accounts, potential identity theft, and breach of data privacy.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker injects a script into a web page that, when executed, retrieves authentication tokens improperly stored in browser local storage, allowing them to impersonate the user and access restricted areas of the web application. Another scenario involves an attacker leveraging a browser vulnerability to obtain personal data stored in cookies, which can then be used for unauthorized transactions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1055.005 - Thread Local Storage

threat.name: Man-in-the-middle attacks
threat.desc:
General threat description
An adversary takes advantage of vulnerable communication channels by intercepting and altering messages exchanged between the web client and the server. This malicious activity can result in unintended exposure of sensitive data, compromise of user sessions, and execution of unauthorized operations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Individuals or entities with access to the network path between the web client and server, potentially exploiting unsecured connections, such as public Wi-Fi, or leveraging malware to eavesdrop on and alter the communication. These adversaries might use tools to modify the traffic or credentials to intrude into the communication flow.
Impacts
The consequences of this threat can include privacy violations through data leaks, loss of control over user accounts due to session hijacking, and the possibility for the attacker to perform actions on behalf of the victim, leading to further unauthorized activities and damages.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. A user connects to a public Wi-Fi and accesses a web service; an attacker on the same network intercepts the unsecured traffic, gaining access to sensitive information input by the user. 2. An attacker implants malware on a victim's machine, which captures and modifies requests and responses between the web client and the server, possibly allowing unauthorized transactions in the victim's online banking session. 3. During a session, the attacker injects commands to perform actions under the user's credentials, such as changing account settings or initiating transfers, without the user's consent.

component.desc: AWS service that Stores questions, answers, passages and usage data.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Configure Amazon Cognito authentication for OpenSearch Dashboards
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to your Amazon OpenSearch dashboards, you can authenticate users using Amazon Cognito. This method allows you to take advantage of Amazon Cognito's user pools and identity pools to manage and authenticate users. Below are the steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Create an Amazon Cognito User Pool: Start by setting up a User Pool in Amazon Cognito. User Pools are user directories that provide sign-up and sign-in options for your application users. For more details, refer to the AWS documentation on Amazon Cognito User Pools.

  2. Create an Amazon Cognito Identity Pool: Establish an Identity Pool that enables you to obtain temporary AWS credentials for your users, thus allowing them to access AWS resources. You can link this Identity Pool to your User Pool in order to authenticate users with their credentials. For a comprehensive guide, see Amazon Cognito Identity Pools.

  3. Configure OpenSearch Security Settings: Navigate to the OpenSearch Service console. Under the security settings for your OpenSearch domain, choose Amazon Cognito for the authentication system. Fill in the User Pool ID and Identity Pool ID that you created in the previous steps. You will also need to configure the App Client ID and callback URLs. Detailed instructions are available at Authenticating Dashboard Users with Amazon Cognito.

  4. Verify and Test: Ensure that the setup is correctly implemented by testing the login flow. Access the OpenSearch Dashboards and verify you can securely log in using an Amazon Cognito authenticated user account.

For further information and security best practices, refer to the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation available at AWS OpenSearch Service Security.

countermeasure.name: Configure JWT authentication and authorization
countermeasure.desc:
JSON Web Token (JWT) authentication and authorization provide secure token-based authentication for AWS OpenSearch. Implementing this countermeasure ensures that only authenticated and authorized users can access your OpenSearch domains, enhancing security by reducing unauthorized access risks.

To enable JWT authentication and authorization for AWS OpenSearch:

  1. Ensure that your OpenSearch domain is configured to use Fine-Grained Access Control (FGAC). FGAC provides the capability to define access policies based on users and roles.
  2. Generate JWTs through a trusted Identity Provider (IdP) such as Amazon Cognito, Auth0, or any other compliant IdP. The IdP should support OpenID Connect (OIDC) protocol for JWT issuance.
  3. Configure your OpenSearch domain to accept JWTs by setting up the appropriate issuer and audience fields. These fields will correspond to the IdPs metadata and ensure that OpenSearch validates the JWT correctly.
  4. Create fine-grained access control policies within OpenSearch to map users, roles, and permission sets based on attributes within the JWT. This mapping allows for precise access control over OpenSearch resources.
  5. Test JWT authentication by generating a JWT from your IdP and accessing your OpenSearch endpoint using this token. Verify that access is granted or denied according to the FGAC policies youve configured.

Detailed steps and code samples are available in the AWS OpenSearch Service documentation: JSON Web Tokens. Additionally, ensure you're familiar with AWS OpenSearch security best practices to safeguard your OpenSearch resources effectively.

countermeasure.name: Create an interface VPC endpoint
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Amazon OpenSearch Service domain, setting up a service-managed VPC endpoint is essential. This setup ensures that network traffic between your Amazon VPC and OpenSearch Service domain remains within the AWS network, significantly reducing exposure to potential threats and unauthorized access.

Follow these steps to configure an OpenSearch Service-managed VPC endpoint:

  1. Create a VPC: Ensure that you have a VPC in place to which you can attach the endpoint. If you don't have one, create a VPC using the Amazon VPC console or the AWS CLI. For more details, visit Creating a VPC.

  2. Create Subnets: Set up private subnets within the VPC if they don't already exist. OpenSearch Service-managed endpoints require subnets within your VPC. For more information, see the VPC Subnets documentation.

  3. Set up Security Groups: Configure security groups to control inbound and outbound traffic to and from the VPC endpoint. Security groups act as virtual firewalls, allowing you to specify traffic rules. Refer to the Security Groups documentation for detailed guidance.

  4. Configure VPC Endpoints: Navigate to the Amazon VPC console, select "Endpoints," and create a new endpoint. Choose the OpenSearch Service as the service name and attach it to your specific VPC and subnets. Reference the VPC Endpoints documentation for step-by-step instructions.

  5. Update OpenSearch Domain: Alter the network settings of your OpenSearch domain to associate it with the newly created VPC endpoint. This step ensures that traffic to your OpenSearch domain traverses the configured VPC endpoint. Specific instructions can be found under Managing VPC in OpenSearch.

  6. Test Endpoint Connectivity: Finally, validate the configuration by testing connectivity to your OpenSearch domain through the VPC endpoint. Make sure that all traffic routes securely and verify access restrictions.

Implementing an OpenSearch Service-managed VPC endpoint is crucial for enhancing security posture by securing network traffic and restricting unauthorized access. For further security best practices, consult the OpenSearch Service security documentation.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security of your stored data in AWS OpenSearch, it is crucial to enable encryption of data at rest using AWS Key Management Service (KMS). This countermeasure helps prevent unauthorized access to your data and ensures compliance with security best practices.

Steps to Enable Encryption at Rest using AWS KMS:

  1. Navigate to the AWS Management Console.

  2. Open the AWS OpenSearch Service console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/opensearch.

  3. Select the OpenSearch domain where you want to enable encryption.

  4. In the 'Actions' dropdown menu, choose Edit security configuration.

  5. Scroll down to the Encryption at rest section.

  6. Check the box to enable encryption at rest.

  7. From the KMS master key dropdown, select an existing KMS key or create a new one. For more detailed guidance on creating and managing KMS keys, refer to the AWS KMS documentation.

  8. After selecting the KMS key, click Save changes to apply the configuration.

For further details on enabling encryption at rest with AWS OpenSearch, please refer to the official Encryption at rest documentation.

Additional information regarding AWS OpenSearch security practices can be found in the AWS OpenSearch Security Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
Enable Fine-Grained Access Control to Provide Security at the Index, Document, and Field Level

Fine-grained access control (FGAC) allows you to secure your AWS Opensearch Service domains more precisely by controlling access at the index, document, and field levels. This countermeasure ensures that only authorized users can access sensitive data, thereby enhancing the security posture of your OpenSearch environment.

To implement fine-grained access control, follow these steps:

Step 1: Enable Fine-Grained Access Control

When creating a new domain or modifying an existing domain, enable fine-grained access control. In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the OpenSearch Service and click on your domain. Under the "Security configuration" section, enable the "Enable fine-grained access control" option.

Step 2: Configure Master User

Define a master user who has full access to the domain. The master user can then configure access control policies. In the "Fine-grained access control" settings, specify the master user ARN or username, which will be used for all initial domain configuration activities.

Step 3: Define Index Patterns and Roles

Create index patterns to define which indices the roles will have access to. Roles allow you to map permissions to users and groups while defining read, write, and manage access to specific indices. For each role, specify the index permissions and document-level security queries.

  1. Navigate to "Security" > "Roles" in Kibana.
  2. Create a new role and define the necessary privileges (e.g., read, write) for the specific index patterns.

Step 4: Assign Users to Roles

Assign users or groups to the roles you've created. This can be done through the AWS IAM integration or by using the internal user database within the OpenSearch Service.

Step 5: Configure Field-Level Security

Field-level security settings can further restrict access to specific fields within documents:

  • Navigate to "Security" > "Roles" in Kibana.
  • Edit the role to include field-level security settings, specifying which fields are to be hidden or included.

By following these steps, you can effectively use fine-grained access control in AWS OpenSearch, ensuring that users only access the data they are authorized to view or modify.

For further details and advanced configurations, refer to the official AWS OpenSearch Service documentation on fine-grained access control: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/fgac.html

For comprehensive security practices including encryption, network security, and audit logging, refer to the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/security.html

countermeasure.name: Enable SAML authentication for OpenSearch Dashboards
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your OpenSearch Dashboards, it is recommended to configure SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language) authentication using existing identity providers (IdPs). This integration allows your users to log in to OpenSearch Dashboards using their corporate credentials, leveraging your organization's existing identity management system. The following steps guide the process of configuring SAML authentication:

  1. Setup Identity Provider (IdP):

    Ensure that your IdP supports SAML 2.0. Obtain the necessary metadata URL or file from your IdP that will be required during configuration. Common IdPs include Okta, OneLogin, and Microsoft Azure AD.

  2. Access OpenSearch Service Console:

    Navigate to the Amazon OpenSearch Service console. Select the domain where you want to configure SAML authentication and go to the "Security" section.
    Reference Link

  3. Configure SAML Authentication:

    In the SAML authentication section, provide the following details:

    • Metadata URL/File: Provide the metadata URL or upload the metadata file from your IdP.
    • Entity ID: This is a unique identifier for the SAML service provider. Ensure it matches the Entity ID in your IdP configuration.
    • Service Provider Endpoints: Configure endpoints such as Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) URL that AWS OpenSearch uses to receive SAML assertions from the IdP.
  4. Update Roles and Mappings:

    Define the mappings between SAML attributes and OpenSearch roles. This mapping allows users to inherit specific permissions based on their SAML assertions.
    Reference Link

  5. Testing and Validation:

    After you complete the configuration, perform a series of tests to ensure that the SAML authentication is working correctly. Have users attempt to log in using their corporate credentials to confirm successful integration.

For detailed instructions and additional configuration options, refer to the official AWS documentation:
AWS OpenSearch Service Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use aws SourceArn in policies
countermeasure.desc:
To mitigate the confused deputy problem and ensure that permissions are correctly scoped to specific resources, you should use the aws:SourceArn global condition context key in your IAM policies. This technique ensures that only requests originating from the specified Amazon Resource Name (ARN) can access your AWS OpenSearch Service resources.

Here is a step-by-step guide for implementing this control:

  1. Identify the ARNs of the services or resources that require access to your OpenSearch indices or clusters.
  2. Create or modify the appropriate IAM policy or resource policy to include the aws:SourceArn condition key. This key verifies that the call to access the OpenSearch resource is coming from the correct source.
  3. Ensure that the policy condition specifically restricts permissions to the identified ARNs.

Below is an example of an IAM policy that uses aws:SourceArn to limit access:


{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": "es:ESHttpGet",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:es:region:account-id:domain/your-domain/*",
            "Condition": {
                "StringEquals": {
                    "aws:SourceArn": "arn:aws:lambda:region:account-id:function:your-lambda-function"
                }
            }
        }
    ]
}

In this example, the policy allows HTTP GET requests to an OpenSearch domain only if the request originates from a specified AWS Lambda function.

For further information on preventing the confused deputy problem and securing your OpenSearch Service resources, refer to the AWS official documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use service-linked roles
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the principle of least privilege while managing AWS OpenSearch Service, it is crucial to implement service-linked roles that delegate the minimal necessary permissions. This security practice helps to mitigate risks associated with overly broad permissions and enhances the overall security posture of your AWS environment.

Follow these steps to implement service-linked roles:

  1. Navigate to the IAM Roles console in AWS Management Console.
  2. Click on the "Create role" button.
  3. Choose "AWS Service" as the trusted entity and select "OpenSearch Service" from the list of services.
  4. Select the "OpenSearchService" use case to automatically attach required policies for the service-linked role.
  5. Review the permissions and ensure that they align with the principle of least privilege. Make modifications if necessary to tailor to your specific requirements.
  6. Provide a role name and optional description, then create the role.

After the role has been created, OpenSearch Service will automatically assume this role to perform actions on your behalf. This ensures that the permissions granted are limited to only what is necessary for OpenSearch Service to function effectively.

For comprehensive information on service-linked roles for OpenSearch, refer to the Service-linked roles documentation.

Additionally, consult the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation for more guidelines on securing your OpenSearch Service environment.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Weak IAM role permissions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate IAM role permissions can result in excessive privileges being exploited by malicious entities, enabling unauthorized access or modifications to AWS resources.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers leveraging insufficiently restrictive IAM roles to gain elevated privileges.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, disruption of services, data loss or corruption, and significant financial or reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an over-permissioned IAM role and uses it to access and exfiltrate sensitive data from an AWS Opensearch cluster, or a compromised account with excessive permissions is used to delete or alter critical infrastructure settings, causing service disruptions.

threat.name: Inadequate access control
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access controls failure can result in unauthorized users gaining access to system resources.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external attackers, rogue employees, and opportunistic insiders who exploit weak access control policies, misconfigured IAM roles, or exposed access credentials.
Impacts
This can lead to data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized modifications, and compromised system integrity, potentially resulting in financial losses and damage to organizational reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers an exposed AWS access key on a public code repository and uses it to gain access to OpenSearch, where they extract sensitive data. Additionally, a disgruntled employee who retains access after termination could potentially alter or delete critical data due to poor access revocation practices.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification

threat.name: Confused deputy problem
threat.desc:
General threat description
A security issue arises when an entity without direct permissions can manipulate a more-privileged entity into performing actions on its behalf. This can lead to unauthorized access or modification of data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers. They may exploit vulnerabilities in the permission settings or leverage social engineering techniques to coerce privileged entities.
Impacts
The impacts can range from unauthorized data access and data manipulation to privilege escalation and potential data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could craft a malicious API request that appears legitimate, tricking a more-privileged service into executing it and accessing restricted data. Alternatively, a compromised low-privilege account could send commands that appear to come from a legitimate high-privilege service, leading to unauthorized data modifications.

threat.name: Single sign-on vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Configuring SSO without adequate security measures can expose the system to various security threats.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, or automated scripts which can exploit vulnerabilities such as weak authentication protocols, inadequate encryption, or misconfigured access controls in the SSO implementation.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, service disruptions, and compromised user accounts, which can lead to significant financial losses and damage to an organizations reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker may exploit a poorly configured SSO system by using phishing techniques to steal valid user credentials and gain access to multiple linked applications. In another scenario, a malicious insider might leverage inadequate access controls to elevate their privileges and perform unauthorized actions across the network.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to stored data, which can lead to data leakage or manipulation.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised credentials, misconfigured access controls.
Impacts
Loss of sensitive or proprietary information, financial loss, regulatory fines, damage to reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the AWS Opensearch cluster using stolen credentials and extracts sensitive business data. Alternatively, a misconfiguration in access controls allows an unauthorized user to manipulate stored data, leading to inaccurate business analytics and decision-making.

threat.name: Unregulated network access
threat.desc:
General threat description
When an AWS Opensearch instance is configured with direct and unfiltered network access, it can become susceptible to unauthorized access and potential security breaches. This misconfiguration could lead to exposure of sensitive data and undermine the integrity and availability of the Opensearch service.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors including cybercriminals, malicious insiders, or external adversaries could exploit unfiltered network access to gain unauthorized entry. They might use network scanning tools, automated scripts, or brute force attacks to identify and infiltrate the misconfigured Opensearch instance.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to an Opensearch instance can have several severe impacts, including data theft, data corruption, loss of sensitive information, disruption of services, financial losses due to mitigation and response efforts, and damage to an organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker scans the network for open and unfiltered access points, discovers the misconfigured Opensearch instance, and exfiltrates sensitive business data. 2. A malicious insider connects to the Opensearch instance via unfiltered network access, manipulates or deletes significant indexes, causing data integrity issues and operational disruptions. 3. An external hacker leverages automated tools to identify unprotected Opensearch instances and executes exploits to inject malicious data or ransomware, demanding a ransom for data restoration.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Insufficient authentication management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper authentication management may lead to compromised security in OpenSearch Dashboards.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit weak or misconfigured authentication mechanisms to gain unauthorized access to OpenSearch Dashboards. This can occur through various methods such as brute force attacks, exploiting default credentials, or phishing.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can result in disclosure of sensitive information, data manipulation, unauthorized administrative actions, and overall loss of data integrity and confidentiality.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a brute force attack to guess weak administrator credentials and gains full access to OpenSearch Dashboards. Another scenario could involve an internal actor exploiting default credentials that were not changed after initial setup, leading to unauthorized access and potential data tampering.

threat.name: Unsecured authentication
threat.desc:
General threat description
The use of weak or inadequate authentication methods can lead to unauthorized access to AWS Opensearch clusters, exposing sensitive data and compromising system integrity.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or script kiddies. Attack vectors often involve brute force attacks, phishing, or exploiting weak passwords and inadequate multi-factor authentication.
Impacts
Impacts include data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized data manipulation, service disruptions, and potential legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could launch a brute force attack against an Opensearch cluster's login interface, eventually gaining access due to weak passwords. Alternatively, an attacker could exploit a lack of multi-factor authentication to gain access through compromised credentials obtained via a phishing campaign.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Deny creation and usage of Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Deny the action iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential to prevent the creation of long-term Bedrock API keys. Where business exceptions are required, restrict creation with IAM condition keys, such as setting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialServiceName to bedrock.amazonaws.com and limiting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialAgeDays to the minimum acceptable value (e.g., 90 days).
  • Deny the action bedrock:CallWithBearerToken to block the use of Bedrock bearer API keys, regardless of type. Where partial enforcement is necessary, scope the condition bedrock:bearerTokenType to explicitly block either SHORT_TERM or LONG_TERM keys.

References

  • Control permissions for generating and using Amazon Bedrock API keys

countermeasure.name: Deploy models in isolated accounts to restrict unauthorized access
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Bedrock models are deployed in isolated AWS accounts, limiting access to authorized users and preventing unauthorized parties, including model providers, from accessing or manipulating the models. Use account isolation strategies such as AWS Organizations and service control policies (SCPs) to restrict access and control resource sharing between accounts. This setup enhances security by ensuring that models are protected from external threats and unauthorized internal actions, while allowing for stricter governance and monitoring of account-specific activities. Regularly audit account configurations and permissions to maintain strong isolation boundaries.

countermeasure.name: Detect and alert on Bedrock bearer key usage
countermeasure.desc:
• Configure detections for Bedrock bearer key usage by alerting on CloudTrail events with additionalEventData.callWithBearerToken=true. Distinguish normal service activity from suspicious access by correlating principal, source IP, and user agent, and prioritize findings originating from unexpected principals or networks.
  • Monitor iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential events where requestParameters.service equals bedrock.amazonaws.com to detect attempted or successful creation of long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • Enable detections for sensitive Bedrock changes (e.g., creation, update, or deletion of guardrails) and treat these as high-priority when they follow bearer-token activity.

References

  • Monitor Amazon Bedrock API calls using CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Implement API request signing with access keys or temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure Amazon Bedrock access uses IAM roles with SigV4-signed SDK/CLI requests; do not use Bedrock bearer API keys unless explicitly approved with compensating controls. If Bedrock API keys exist, enforce minimal permissions and short lifetimes, and apply the dedicated controls to deny creation and usage of bearer keys.

Use temporary credentials via AWS STS and enforce strict IAM policies. Configure clients to sign requests (SigV4) and validate that unsigned/bearer requests are rejected. Rotate credentials regularly and monitor for anomalies.

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/api-keys-permissions.html

countermeasure.name: Isolate foundation model tuning data in private instances to prevent leakage

Implement strict access controls to limit who can view and interact with the tuning data. Regularly monitor and audit resource usage to confirm data remains isolated and protected from unintended exposure or reuse, ensuring compliance with privacy regulations and safeguarding sensitive information.

countermeasure.name: Prefer roles and SigV4 over Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Use IAM roles and SigV4-signed SDK or CLI calls for accessing Amazon Bedrock instead of bearer API keys. This ensures requests are cryptographically signed and traceable, reducing the risk of credential misuse.
  • If the use of API keys cannot be fully avoided, enforce strict least-privilege policies, apply the shortest possible key lifetimes, and configure dedicated monitoring to detect and respond to bearer token usage.

  • Replace it with custom IAM policies that follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the actions strictly required by the workload (for example, bedrock:InvokeModel).
  • Regularly audit attached policies to ensure no over-privileged permissions remain and that policies continue to align with current operational needs.

countermeasure.name: Scan for Bedrock API keys in code and artifacts
countermeasure.desc:
• Add Bedrock-specific patterns to secret scanning to detect both long- and short-term keys. Include a rule for long-term keys prefixed with ABSK and a rule for short-term keys that include bedrock-api-key-.
  • Integrate these patterns with GitHub secret scanning (including push protection where available) and CI pre-commit hooks so commits are blocked or flagged before merging.
  • On detection, automatically revoke the exposed key, rotate any dependent credentials, and open an incident ticket with links to the offending commit or artifact for traceability.

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount conditions to limit access to trusted entities
countermeasure.desc: Implement the aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount conditions in resource-based policies to ensure that AWS Bedrock resources are only accessed by trusted sources. These conditions restrict access based on the specific ARN or AWS account making the request, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. To apply this control, update your IAM policies with conditions that validate the source of the request and ensure that only allowed entities, such as specific roles or trusted accounts, can interact with your Bedrock resources. This helps prevent unauthorized cross-account or cross-service actions that could compromise your environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management||ATLAS - AML.M0005 - Control Access to AI Models and Data at Rest

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize input to prevent malicious patterns in Bedrock API requests
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all user input sent to the AWS Bedrock API is thoroughly validated and sanitized to prevent special characters or malicious patterns from being processed. Input validation should be performed on both server-side and client-side to filter out dangerous inputs like SQL-like commands or unexpected formats. Implement input sanitization to escape or remove special characters, reducing the risk of injection attacks. Regularly test applications with security tools such as static analysis, dynamic testing, and penetration testing to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities related to input handling. This will protect your Bedrock environment from prompt injection attacks and other input-based exploits.

reference.name: Prompt injection security

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confuse deputy attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A confused deputy attack occurs when AWS Bedrock is tricked into performing actions on behalf of an unauthorized user or service. This happens when cross-service permissions are misconfigured, allowing an attacker to leverage Bedrocks privileges to access or manipulate resources they would not normally have access to.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers or compromised services that exploit weak cross-service permissions.
  • Misconfigured resource policies that fail to validate the origin of requests.

Impacts
Unauthorized data access, resource manipulation, and potential service disruptions, leading to security breaches and data leaks.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a misconfigured cross-service role to trick Bedrock into accessing sensitive resources like model configurations or datasets, which they are not authorized to access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data privacy violation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data privacy violations occur when sensitive or personal data processed by AWS Bedrock is improperly accessed, exposed, or misused, breaching compliance standards such as GDPR or HIPAA.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders or external attackers exploiting misconfigurations in Bedrock.
  • Third-party model providers mishandling data.

Impacts
Financial penalties, reputational damage, and legal consequences due to non-compliance with privacy regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits weak access controls to download sensitive customer data used in fine-tuning models.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0048.001 - Reputational Harm

threat.name: Insecure API access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure API access occurs when unauthorized parties exploit weak access controls or improper API configurations, allowing them to misuse AWS Bedrock's API, leading to unauthorized actions, data leaks, or exposure of sensitive resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting weak API authentication or improperly configured API keys.
  • Insiders abusing improperly scoped API permissions.

Impacts
Data theft, unauthorized model access, or abuse of resources, leading to financial loss and regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages exposed API keys to access Bedrock resources, extracting sensitive data used for model customization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1102 - Web Service||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

threat.name: Model theft or misuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Model theft or misuse happens when unauthorized individuals gain access to AWS Bedrock's foundational or fine-tuned models. This can lead to intellectual property theft, unauthorized usage, or exploitation of proprietary models for malicious or unintended purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting misconfigurations or weak access controls to retrieve models.
  • Insiders with excessive privileges accessing and leaking sensitive models.

Impacts
Loss of proprietary model data, financial loss, damage to intellectual property, and competitive disadvantage.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to a custom fine-tuned model through improperly secured APIs and uses it to replicate the model for personal gain or to sell it to competitors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

threat.name: Prompt injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Prompt injection attacks occur when an attacker manipulates input prompts to deceive or control the behavior of AI models in AWS Bedrock. These attacks exploit the model's ability to process natural language input, injecting malicious commands or misleading data, resulting in unintended outputs or actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers inputting malicious prompts to alter the models response.
  • Insiders crafting prompts to manipulate model behavior or extract sensitive information.

Impacts
Manipulated model outputs, potential exposure of confidential data, reputational damage, and compromised decision-making in AI-driven applications.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker submits a carefully crafted prompt that causes the model to reveal sensitive data or produce misleading results, leading to incorrect or damaging business decisions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys
threat.desc:
Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys occurs when long-term or short-term keys are used instead of standard AWS authentication. Long-term keys automatically create IAM users with broad default permissions, while short-term keys are generated client-side without CloudTrail creation visibility. As bearer tokens, leaked keys can be misused to access or modify Bedrock resources outside of intended security controls.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders generating or retaining long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • External attackers obtaining leaked bearer tokens from public repositories or compromised systems.
  • Malicious actors abusing the over-privileged AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy assigned to auto-created IAM users.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to Bedrock models, datasets, or guardrails.
  • Potential deletion or modification of security guardrails.
  • Data confidentiality and integrity risks from model misuse.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A leaked long-term Bedrock API key on GitHub is used to invoke Bedrock models and disable guardrails.
  • An attacker compromises a developer machine and retrieves a short-term bearer token, allowing them to run inference requests undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1134 - Access Token Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Deny creation and usage of Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Deny the action iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential to prevent the creation of long-term Bedrock API keys. Where business exceptions are required, restrict creation with IAM condition keys, such as setting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialServiceName to bedrock.amazonaws.com and limiting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialAgeDays to the minimum acceptable value (e.g., 90 days).
  • Deny the action bedrock:CallWithBearerToken to block the use of Bedrock bearer API keys, regardless of type. Where partial enforcement is necessary, scope the condition bedrock:bearerTokenType to explicitly block either SHORT_TERM or LONG_TERM keys.

References

  • Control permissions for generating and using Amazon Bedrock API keys

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management||ATLAS - AML.M0019 - Control Access to AI Models and Data in Production

countermeasure.name: Deploy models in isolated accounts to restrict unauthorized access
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Bedrock models are deployed in isolated AWS accounts, limiting access to authorized users and preventing unauthorized parties, including model providers, from accessing or manipulating the models. Use account isolation strategies such as AWS Organizations and service control policies (SCPs) to restrict access and control resource sharing between accounts. This setup enhances security by ensuring that models are protected from external threats and unauthorized internal actions, while allowing for stricter governance and monitoring of account-specific activities. Regularly audit account configurations and permissions to maintain strong isolation boundaries.

reference.name: Generative AI for the AWS SRA

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1030 - Network Segmentation||ATLAS - AML.M0019 - Control Access to AI Models and Data in Production

countermeasure.name: Detect and alert on Bedrock bearer key usage
countermeasure.desc:
• Configure detections for Bedrock bearer key usage by alerting on CloudTrail events with additionalEventData.callWithBearerToken=true. Distinguish normal service activity from suspicious access by correlating principal, source IP, and user agent, and prioritize findings originating from unexpected principals or networks.
  • Monitor iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential events where requestParameters.service equals bedrock.amazonaws.com to detect attempted or successful creation of long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • Enable detections for sensitive Bedrock changes (e.g., creation, update, or deletion of guardrails) and treat these as high-priority when they follow bearer-token activity.

References

  • Monitor Amazon Bedrock API calls using CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Implement API request signing with access keys or temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure Amazon Bedrock access uses IAM roles with SigV4-signed SDK/CLI requests; do not use Bedrock bearer API keys unless explicitly approved with compensating controls. If Bedrock API keys exist, enforce minimal permissions and short lifetimes, and apply the dedicated controls to deny creation and usage of bearer keys.

Use temporary credentials via AWS STS and enforce strict IAM policies. Configure clients to sign requests (SigV4) and validate that unsigned/bearer requests are rejected. Rotate credentials regularly and monitor for anomalies.

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/api-keys-permissions.html

reference.name: Getting started with the AWS API

countermeasure.name: Isolate foundation model tuning data in private instances to prevent leakage
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that when tuning a foundation model in AWS Bedrock, all customer data is isolated in a private instance to prevent unauthorized access or reuse by model providers. Use account-specific resources such as AWS PrivateLink and VPC to securely connect to the Bedrock service without exposing data to external networks. Implement strict access controls to limit who can view and interact with the tuning data. Regularly monitor and audit resource usage to confirm data remains isolated and protected from unintended exposure or reuse, ensuring compliance with privacy regulations and safeguarding sensitive information.

reference.name: Security in Amazon Bedrock

countermeasure.name: Prefer roles and SigV4 over Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Use IAM roles and SigV4-signed SDK or CLI calls for accessing Amazon Bedrock instead of bearer API keys. This ensures requests are cryptographically signed and traceable, reducing the risk of credential misuse.
  • If the use of API keys cannot be fully avoided, enforce strict least-privilege policies, apply the shortest possible key lifetimes, and configure dedicated monitoring to detect and respond to bearer token usage.

References

  • A new type of long-lived key on AWS: Bedrock API keys

countermeasure.name: Reduce privileges of auto-created IAM user
countermeasure.desc:
• For any existing long-term Bedrock API keys, remove the AWS-managed AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy, as it grants broad permissions that exceed most workload requirements.
  • Replace it with custom IAM policies that follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the actions strictly required by the workload (for example, bedrock:InvokeModel).
  • Regularly audit attached policies to ensure no over-privileged permissions remain and that policies continue to align with current operational needs.

References

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers obtaining leaked bearer tokens from public repositories or compromised systems.
  • Malicious actors abusing the over-privileged AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy assigned to auto-created IAM users.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to Bedrock models, datasets, or guardrails.
  • Potential deletion or modification of security guardrails.
  • Data confidentiality and integrity risks from model misuse.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A leaked long-term Bedrock API key on GitHub is used to invoke Bedrock models and disable guardrails.
  • An attacker compromises a developer machine and retrieves a short-term bearer token, allowing them to run inference requests undetected.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Deny creation and usage of Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Deny the action iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential to prevent the creation of long-term Bedrock API keys. Where business exceptions are required, restrict creation with IAM condition keys, such as setting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialServiceName to bedrock.amazonaws.com and limiting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialAgeDays to the minimum acceptable value (e.g., 90 days).
  • Deny the action bedrock:CallWithBearerToken to block the use of Bedrock bearer API keys, regardless of type. Where partial enforcement is necessary, scope the condition bedrock:bearerTokenType to explicitly block either SHORT_TERM or LONG_TERM keys.

References

  • Control permissions for generating and using Amazon Bedrock API keys
